issues.description: The problem statement (and the template Main.java) expect concrete animal classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat that extend Animal and implement the respective interfaces. The solution repository does not provide implementations with those names; instead it provides SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat classes. This name mismatch between the expected class identifiers (Seal/Pig/Goat) and the solution's concrete classes (SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat) is a structural inconsistency that will confuse students comparing their work to the reference solution or trying to run the example Main. In particular, the problem text and UML repeatedly refer to Seal/Pig/Goat (and the template Main constructs those types), but the solution's concrete types use different class names. This difference also affects outputs that use getClass().getSimpleName() (the printed animal type will be e.g. "SpaceSeal" instead of the expected "Seal").
issues.suggested_fix: Align the concrete class names between specification/template and the solution. Either (A) rename the solution classes SpaceSeal, SpacePig, SpaceGoat to Seal, Pig, Goat (and adjust their constructors/messages accordingly), or (B) add concrete wrapper classes named Seal, Pig, Goat that delegate to or extend the existing Space* classes so that the solution repository provides the expected class names. Ensure messageOnMilk()/messageOnRide() use the expected animal type naming (or rely on getClass().getSimpleName()) so printed text matches the problem description and the example Main.

issues.description: The problem statement and template consistently refer to the concrete animal classes as Seal, Pig, and Goat (students are asked to implement Seal, Pig, Goat and the template Main creates Seal, Pig, Goat). The solution repository instead provides concrete implementations named SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This naming mismatch means students reading the solution will see different class identifiers than the ones they were asked to create, and output strings in the solution include the "Space" prefix (e.g., "SpaceGoat Buttinsky is milked") which deviates from the expected form "Goat Buttinsky is milked". This creates a conceptual mapping burden: students must infer that SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat correspond to the intended Seal/Pig/Goat entities rather than seeing the exact expected names.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the concrete classes in the solution repository from SpaceSeal, SpacePig, SpaceGoat to Seal, Pig, and Goat to match the problem statement and template. Also adjust the messageOnMilk()/messageOnRide() outputs to use the class name expected by the exercise (for example build the message using getClass().getSimpleName() + " " + getName() + " is milked" and similarly for riding) so printed strings align with the specification. Alternatively, if the "Space" prefix is intentional, update the problem statement and template to consistently use SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat and change task descriptions accordingly.
